children.name: when you do not care about sth because it is not important to you
not care
children.definition: /nɒt ˈkeəʳ/  if you don’t care about something, it isnotimportantto you:
examples: không quan tâm vì nó không quan trọng
▪ ‘what do you think i should do?’ ‘i don’t care. do what you want.’
not care what/whether/if etc
▪ i like george, and i don’t care what anyone else thinks about him.
▪ i don’t care what my parents say - i am going to the party.
not care about
▪ she doesn’t care about anything except money.

children.name: couldn't care less c1
children.definition: couldn’t care less/ˌkʊdnt keəʳ ˈles/ informalto not careatallabout something:
examples: chẳng quan tâm chút nào
▪ the politicians are making a big deal out of the issue, but most voters couldn’t care less.
couldn’t care less about
▪ shelley couldn’t care less about what other people thought of her.
couldn’t care less whether/if
▪ to be perfectly honest with you, i couldn’t care less whether he comes or not.

children.name: who cares? b2
children.definition: who cares?/so what?/what do i care? /ˌhuː ˈkeəʳz, ˌsəʊ ˈwɒt, ˌwɒt duː ˈaɪ keəʳ/spokeninformalsay this when you do not care about something, because you do not think it is important at all: ai quan tâm? thì sao? sao phải quan tâm ?
examples: ▪ so your house isn’t perfectly clean. who cares?
▪ ‘phil was really angry when he heard what you had done.’ ‘so what? it’s none of his business.’
▪ ‘he says he’s depressed and really short of money.’ ‘what do i care? it’s his own fault.’

children.name: not give a damn
children.definition: /ˌnɒt gɪv ə ˈdæm/  spoken to not care at all about something - use this when you are very annoyed with someone or something: not give a damn about
examples: không quan tâm
▪ you’re so selfish. you don’t give a damn about anyone except for yourself.
not give a damn what/who/why etc
▪ i don’t really give a damn what the press says.

children.name: be past caring
children.definition: /biː ˌpɑːst ˈkeərɪŋǁ-ˌpæst-/  to no longer care about something that you were worried about for a long time, because you realize that the situation cannot be changed:
examples: không còn lo lắng hay quan tâm vì một điều gì đó trước đây đã từng
▪ i used to worry a lot about my weight when i was young, but now i’m past caring.
▪ the company wrote and apologized for their mistake, but by then sarah was past caring.

children.name: for all i care
children.definition: /fər ˌɔːl ˈaɪ ˌkeəʳ/  spoken say this when you do not care at all what someone does or what happens to them, especially when you are annoyed with them:
examples: không quan tâm những điều người khác làm biệt khi bị họ chọc tức
▪ i don’t want to hear any more about her. she can drop dead for all i care.

children.name: let him/her/them (do st)
children.definition: let him/her/them (do something)/ˌlet hɪm (ˈduː something )/ spoken say this when you do not care if someone does what they have threatened to do:
examples: không quan tâm những gì người khác đe dọa làm
▪ ‘brenda says she’s going to quit unless we give her a raise.’ ‘let her quit then. it’s not as if we can’t find another nanny.’
▪ ‘they’re threatening to disconnect the phone unless we pay the bill.’ ‘let them!’

children.name: tough!
children.definition: /tʌf/ spoken informal say this when someone tells you about a problem they have and you do not have any sympathy for them, especially because you feel angry with them:
examples: 'quên chuyện đó đi'
▪ ‘mom, i don’t want to go to school today.’ ‘tough! you’re going anyway.’
▪ ‘can’t we stop? i’m hungry.’ ‘that’s tough. i told you to eat something before we left the house.’

children.name: minor b2
children.definition: minor small and not very likely to have an important effect - used especially about changes, problems, injuries, damage, or differences :
examples: i've made a few minor changes.
the driver suffered minor injuries.
these are just minor problems.

children.name: insignificant c1
children.definition: insignificant/not significant/ˌɪnsɪgˈnɪfɪkənt, nɒt sɪgˈnɪfɪkənt/  not important enough to worry about, especially because there are other problems that are much more serious: không đáng kể
examples: ▪ the level of radiation was considered ‘insignificant’ and not a danger to health.
▪ there is a slight difference in the way men and women are affected by the drug, but this is not really significant.
▪ after a week of negotiations, the differences between the two sides are now relatively insignificant.
▪ eu financiers say that recent problems on the us stock markets were not significant for europe.

children.name: petty c2
children.definition: petty/ˈpeti/  something such as a problem, argument, or worry that is petty is so unimportant that it seems silly or selfish for someone to talk or worry about: nhỏ nhen, vụn vặt
examples: ▪ we started having arguments over petty little things.
▪ the meeting spent too much time on petty issues, and didn’t address the real problem.

children.name: trivial b2
children.definition: trivial unimportant and not serious, and not worth worrying about or spending time or effort on: tầm thướng, nhỏ nhặt
examples: the issue of where the peace talks will be held may seem trivial, but to the participants it is very important.
no, i don’t think your question is trivial at all.
trivial problem/matter/complaint etc
we were punished for the most trivial offences.
her feelings for simon seemedtrivial by comparison.
why waste time watching trivial tv programs?
trivia[u] information or facts that are not important and have no real use or value:
the magazine was full of trivia and gossip.
i find that i can remember trivia such as old sports results, but i can’t remember the things that i really need to remember.

children.name: unimportant b1
children.definition: not important/unimportant /nɒtɪmˈpɔːʳtənt, ˌʌnɪmˈpɔːʳtənt◂/  formal not likely to cause problems or to have an important effect on something: không quan trọng
examples: ▪ ‘i forgot to add the olive oil.’ ‘don’t worry -- it’s not important.
▪ i don’t want to waste time arguing over unimportant details.
it is not important that you understand everything at this stage.
▪ critics have dismissed his work as unimportant.

children.name: small a2
children.definition: small not important and not likely to take long to deal with or correct: nhỏ
examples: ▪ your essay’s very good -- there are just one or two small points i’d like to discuss.
▪ there were a couple of small things i wanted to talk to you about.
▪ we had a few small problems when we were putting the design together, but it works fine now.

children.name: be of no importance b1
children.definition: be of no importance/biː əv ˌnəʊ ɪmˈpɔːʳtəns/  formal to not be important, and be unlikely to affect anything in a serious way: không nghiêm trọng, không quan trọng
examples: ▪ if you’re capable of doing the job, your age is of no importance.
▪ these are small details and probably of no importance.

children.name: small and not making much difference to sth
slight b2
children.definition: slight/slaɪt/  small and not very important or not very noticeable:
examples: ▪ there has been a slight change of plan.
▪ the doctor says there has been a slight improvement in her condition.
▪ he was a good friend - always available to help at the slightest sign of need.
not the slightestnone at all
▪ tom? i haven’t the slightest idea where he is
.▪ us foreign policy at the time hadn’t made the slightest difference in the situation.

children.name: infinitesimal x
children.definition: infinitesimal/ˌɪnfɪnɪˈtesəməl◂, ˌɪnfɪnəˈtesəməl◂/  an infinitesimal amount, risk etc is so small that it makes very little difference or is not worth worrying about:
examples: ▪ even an infinitesimal change in temperature will be recorded by the equipment.
▪ i’d say the chances of your catching the disease are infinitesimal.
infinitesimally[adverb]
▪ the eggs of the lice are infinitesimally small and very easy to miss.

children.name: tiny b1
children.definition: tiny/ˈtaɪni/  extremely small:
examples: ▪ i’ve made one or two tiny alterations, but otherwise the house is the same as when i bought it.
▪ there’s been a tiny decrease in the number of people out of work.

children.name: minor b2
children.definition: minor/ˈmaɪnəʳ/  not important enough or serious enough to worry about:
examples: ▪ she fell off her horse, but suffered only minor injuries.
▪ the contract seems fine, except for a few minor details.
▪ with one or two minor changes, the course is the same as last year.

children.name: small a2
children.definition: small/smɔːl/
examples: ▪ i want to make a few small changes to the design.
▪ there is still one small problem that we haven’t dealt with.
▪ government statistics showed a small drop in the annual rate of inflation.

children.name: minute c2
children.definition: minute/maɪˈnjuːtǁ-ˈnuːt/  a change or difference that is minute is so small that it is difficult to see it or notice any effects resulting from it:
examples: ▪ the equipment records minute changes in air pressure.

children.name: subsidiary x
children.definition: subsidiary/səbˈsɪdiəriǁ-dieri/ formala subsidiary idea, question, subject etc is less important than the main one but it is connected with it:
examples: phụ ( ko quan trọng bằng cái chính được liên kết với nó )
▪ if you take the english literature course, you can do linguistics as a subsidiary subject.
subsidiary to
the formulation of a lasting peace settlement was the main objective, and everything else was seen as subsidiary to it.

children.name: incidental x
children.definition: incidental/ˌɪnsɪˈdentl◂, ˌɪnsəˈdentl◂/ happeningorexistingin connection with or as a result of something else that is more important:
examples: phụ ( đi kèm với cái chính )
▪ the red cross will provide money for food, housing, and incidental expenses.
incidental to
▪ the puzzles are fun, but are incidental to the plot of the book.
purely incidental
▪ the concert is just for fun, really. any profit we make from it will be purely incidental.

children.name: of less importance b1
children.definition: be of secondary/minor/less etc importance/biː əv ˌsekəndəri ɪmˈpɔːʳtənsǁ-deri-/  to be not very important compared to other things:
examples: quan trọng thứ yếu
▪ it’s the perfect job for him - the salary is of secondary importance.
▪ police are increasingly regarding cannabis use as being of minor importance compared with other forms of crime.
▪ we must stop treating mental illness as being of less importance than physical disabilities.

children.name: secondary x
children.definition: secondary/ˈsekəndəriǁ-deri/  less important than the main subject, problem etc: thứ yếu
examples: ▪ the government sees unemployment as a secondary issue.
▪ the study found that women were often reduced to secondary roles in the workplace.
secondary to
▪ tourism is secondary to oil revenues as a source of income.

children.name: marginal c2
children.definition: marginal/ˈmɑːʳdʒɪnəl, ˈmɑːʳdʒənəl/  too small and unimportant to have any useful or noticeable effect:
examples: ▪ the difference between the two cars is marginal.
▪ a marginal increase in sales

children.name: peripheral x
children.definition: peripheral/pəˈrɪfərəl/ relatingto the main activity, question, or subject, but much less important than it:
examples: ngoại vi, thứ yếu
▪ it is a society in which women’s rights and concerns are still treated as peripheral.
▪ too much money is being spent on peripheral programs when our kids can’t read or do basic math.
peripheral to
▪ the romance was peripheral to the movie’s main plot.

children.name: side issue b1
children.definition: side issue a subject or question that results from or is connected with the main one being considered, but is much less important: phụ , ngoài lề
examples: ▪ the meeting seemed to focus on side issues, without ever really addressing the main point.
▪ one of the side issues that arose was what to do with the old equipment when the new things arrived.

children.name: pale into insignificance x
children.definition: pale into insignificance if someone’s problems or achievements pale into insignificance when they are compared to something else, they are clearly much less important: không thấm vào đâu, có là gì
examples: ▪ our difficulties pale into insignificance when compared to the problems of the homeless.

children.name: insignificant c1
children.definition: insignificant not important enough or powerful enough to worry about or treat seriously: không quan trọng
examples: ▪ the anti-war group was an insignificant minority within the party.
▪ the spies’ payroll included insignificant clerks and highly placed officials.

children.name: the little guy u
children.definition: the little guy especially american, informal a person or organization that is not important because they do not have any power or influence:
examples: những cậu bé ( ám chỉ những người , tổ chức không có nhiều quyền lực, ảnh hưởng )
▪ he got rich trading illegally on the stock market, using the little guy’s money.
▪ when the big retailers open a store, the little guys lose business.

children.name: lightweight x
children.definition: lightweight/ˈlaɪt-weɪt/  someone who is well-known, for example in politics or literature, but is not really respected or considered to be important:
examples: ▪ his books are tremendously popular, but most of the critics regard him as a lightweight.
political/intellectual/literary etc lightweight
▪ it would be dangerous to dismiss her as a political lightweight.

children.name: nobody x
children.definition: a nobody/ə ˈnəʊbədiǁ-bɑːdi/ informalsomeone who is considered to be unimportant because they are not famous, powerful, or rich:
examples: chẳng là cái thá gì cả
▪ he went from being a nobody to being paid $2 million a year.
▪ i felt like a complete nobody when i lost my job.

children.name: not important
children.definition: /nɒt ɪmˈpɔːʳtənt/  không quan trọng
examples: ▪ he’s not really an important figure in the organization.
▪ don’t worry about the critics. they’re not important - they just think they are.

children.name: nonentity x
children.definition: nonentity/nɒˈnentɪti, nɒˈnentətiǁnɑː-/  someone who is not at all important, powerful, or interesting, and has no special qualities or skills: vô danh tiểu tốt
examples: ▪ next to him, the other dancers seemed like nonentities
▪ he packed his government with nonentities, who would never challenge his leadership.

children.name: small fry x
children.definition: small fry informal a person or group who has very little power or importance compared to other people or organizations: cá con
examples: ▪ environmental groups are small fry against the power of the big multinationals.
▪ only the small fry on the drugs scene got caught by the police.

children.name: what you say when sth is not important
it doesn’t matter b2
children.definition: it doesn’t matter/ɪt ˌdʌzənt ˈmætəʳ/spokensay this to tell someone that something is not important and will not cause any serious problems:
examples: không vấn đề gì đâu
▪ ‘we’ve missed the train.’ ‘it doesn’t matter - there’s another one in 10 minutes.’
it doesn’t matter if/whether/what etc
▪ it doesn’t matter if you’re a few minutes late. we’ll wait for you.
▪ it doesn’t matter what other people think. you should do what you think is best.

children.name: it makes no difference b2
children.definition: it makes no difference/it doesn’t make any difference/ɪt ˌmeɪks nəʊ ˈdɪfərəns, ɪt ˌdʌzənt meɪk eni ˈdɪfərəns/ say this when you think something is not important enough toaffectwhat happens or change what someone decides:
examples: không ảnh hưởng gì đâu ( ko ảnh hưởng đến việc gì sảy ra hay một quyết định nào đó )
▪ ‘do you want cash or a cheque?’ ‘it doesn’t make any difference.’
▪ even if she had known he was lying it would have made no difference.
▪ it doesn’t make any difference whether you use fresh berries or frozen ones.
it makes no difference/it doesn’t make any difference to somebody
▪ it makes no difference to me if you want to go.
it makes no difference/it doesn’t make any difference to something
▪ you can have a single room or a double -- it makes no difference to the price.

children.name: it’s not a big deal x
children.definition: it’s no big deal / it’s not a big deal/ɪts ˌnəʊ bɪg ˈdiːl, ɪts ˌnɒt ə bɪg ˈdiːl/spokensay this when you do not think something isimportantorworrying, even though other people may think it is:
examples: chẳng có gì ghê ghớm cả
▪ my leg’s a little sore, but it’s no big deal.
▪ just copy your work onto a disk - it’s no big deal.
▪ she assumed he’d be furious, but the whole incident just wasn’t a big deal to him.

children.name: it’s nothing x
children.definition: it’s nothing/ɪts ˈnʌθɪŋ/spokensay this when you think something is not important and you do not want other people to worry about it: không sao cả
examples: ▪ ‘are you okay?’ ‘yeah, it’s nothing.
’▪ ‘why do you want to speak to danny? is he in trouble again?’ ‘no, it’s nothing, really. we just want to ask a couple of questions.’

children.name: the background c2
children.definition: the background
examples: if someone or something is in the background, they are not the main point of attention
_her worries about her job havefaded intothe background since she learnt about her father's illness.

children.name: not be the end of the world c2
children.definition: not be the end of the worldinformal
examples: if something is not the end of the world, it will not cause very serious problems
_i'm really hoping to win, but it won't be the end of the world if i don't.

children.name: little b1
children.definition: littleadjectiveunimportant
examples: [ before noun ] not very important or serious
_i had a little problem with my car, but it's been fixed now.
_it's often the little things that count the most.
_can i have a little word (= a short discussion about something not very important) with you?

children.name: fringe c2
children.definition: fringenounedge
examples: the outer or less important part of an area, group or activity
_the southern fringe of the city
_the radical fringes of the party
